_**Dragon Ball Z: Battle of Gods**_ ([Japanese](/wiki/Japanese_language
"Japanese language"): ドラゴンボールZ 神と神, [Hepburn](/wiki/Hepburn_romanization
"Hepburn romanization"): _Doragon Bōru Zetto: Kami to Kami_ , lit. "Dragon
Ball Z: God and God") is the eighteenth [Japanese animated](/wiki/Anime
"Anime") feature film based on the _[Dragon Ball](/wiki/Dragon_Ball "Dragon
Ball")_ series and the fourteenth to carry the _[Dragon Ball
Z](/wiki/Dragon_Ball_Z "Dragon Ball Z")_ branding, released in theaters on
March 30, 2013. It is the first [_Dragon Ball_
movie](/wiki/List_of_Dragon_Ball_films "List of Dragon Ball films") in 17
years to have a theatrical release, the last being [the tenth anniversary
movie](/wiki/Dragon_Ball:_The_Path_to_Power "Dragon Ball: The Path to Power")
in 1996, which followed the first three _Dragon Ball_ films and the thirteen
_Dragon Ball Z_ films. Unlike previous theatrical _Dragon Ball_ releases, this
was a full feature-length production with a stand-alone release and not shown
as part of the now-discontinued Toei Anime Fair (formerly the Toei Manga
Matsuri).

It is the first-ever Japanese film to be screened at [IMAX](/wiki/IMAX "IMAX")
Digital Theaters, and was released on [Blu-ray](/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc "Blu-ray
Disc") and [DVD](/wiki/DVD "DVD") on September 13, 2013.
[Funimation](/wiki/Funimation "Funimation") acquired the North American rights
to _Battle of Gods_ and produced an English dub that they co-released with
[20th Century Fox](/wiki/20th_Century_Fox "20th Century Fox") in North
American cinemas in August 2014. [Madman
Entertainment](/wiki/Madman_Entertainment "Madman Entertainment") acquired the
[Australasian](/wiki/Australasia "Australasia") rights and screened the movie
at the 2013 Japanese Film Festival in Australia before screening the English
dub to select theaters in August 2014, and [Manga
Entertainment](/wiki/Manga_Entertainment "Manga Entertainment") released the
film in the United Kingdom in November 2014.

_Battle of Gods_ was the first film considered an official part of the _Dragon
Ball_ storyline, being set during the time skip in chapter 517 of [the
original manga](/wiki/Dragon_Ball_\(manga\) "Dragon Ball \(manga\)"), with
original creator [Akira Toriyama](/wiki/Akira_Toriyama "Akira Toriyama")
deeply involved.[3] The plot involves [Beerus, the God of
Destruction](/wiki/Beerus,_the_God_of_Destruction "Beerus, the God of
Destruction"), learning of the defeat of the galactic overlord
[Freeza](/wiki/Freeza "Freeza") at the hands of [Son Goku](/wiki/Goku "Goku").
Seeking an opponent worthy of his power, Beerus, along with his companion
[Whis](/wiki/Whis "Whis"), travels to the North Galaxy to challenge Goku to a
battle.[4] The [first story
arc](/wiki/List_of_Dragon_Ball_Super_episodes#Battle_of_Gods_Saga "List of
Dragon Ball Super episodes") of _[Dragon Ball Super](/wiki/Dragon_Ball_Super
"Dragon Ball Super")_ , the newest canonical anime series in the _Dragon Ball_
franchise, retells the events of _Battle of Gods_. Some details have been
altered, scenes added, and dialogue expanded to cover the 14-episode arc.

##
Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dragon_Ball_Z:_Battle_of_Gods&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

[Whis](/wiki/List_of_Dragon_Ball_characters#Whis "List of Dragon Ball
characters") wakes [Beerus](/wiki/List_of_Dragon_Ball_characters#Beerus "List
of Dragon Ball characters"), the [God](/wiki/God_\(male_deity\) "God \(male
deity\)") of Destruction, from his long slumber and tells him that
[Frieza](/wiki/Frieza "Frieza") was defeated by a Saiyan. Thirty-nine years
earlier, the Yogen-gyo (予言魚) foretold that a mighty opponent would appear
before Beerus, the Super Saiyan [God](/wiki/Deity "Deity"). Beerus, with Whis,
then tracks down the Saiyan warrior [Goku](/wiki/Goku "Goku"), who defeated
Freeza. On [Kaiō-sama](/wiki/List_of_Dragon_Ball_characters#Kai.C5.8D-sama
"List of Dragon Ball characters")'s planet, Goku proceeds to challenge Beerus.
Despite having powered up to Super Saiyan 3, Goku is ultimately overwhelmed
and defeated in two strikes. Disappointed by the subsequent lack of challenge,
Beerus departs in order to seek out more powerful adversaries on Earth.

Beerus' arrival interrupts [Bulma](/wiki/Bulma "Bulma")'s birthday party.
[Vegeta](/wiki/Vegeta "Vegeta"), who already knew about Beerus, because of a
warning from Kaiō-sama, casts his pride aside in order to put Beerus in a good
mood. Meanwhile, [Pilaf](/wiki/List_of_Dragon_Ball_characters#Pilaf "List of
Dragon Ball characters"), [Mai](/wiki/List_of_Dragon_Ball_characters#Pilaf
"List of Dragon Ball characters"), and
[Shu](/wiki/List_of_Dragon_Ball_characters#Pilaf "List of Dragon Ball
characters") sneak into the party in order to steal the Dragon Balls, but are
not recognized as they have been turned into children; before the events of
the film, they gathered all the Dragon Balls themselves and wished for youth,
but [Shenlong](/wiki/List_of_Dragon_Ball_characters#Shenlong "List of Dragon
Ball characters") made them a little too young. Discovering the three of them,
[Trunks](/wiki/Trunks_\(Dragon_Ball\) "Trunks \(Dragon Ball\)") mistakes Pilaf
for a monkey and fibs to Goten that Mai is his girlfriend, which leads to the
trio being brought in front of the party-goers. When Mai accidentally drops
the Dragon Ball she stole, she takes Trunks hostage, but no one seems
concerned. A drunk [Gohan](/wiki/Gohan_\(Dragon_Ball\) "Gohan \(Dragon
Ball\)") dares Mai to shoot him; he deflects the bullets with one finger, but
one of them hits [Videl](/wiki/List_of_Dragon_Ball_characters#Videl "List of
Dragon Ball characters")'s leg and another one hits Beerus' forehead.
[Dende](/wiki/List_of_Dragon_Ball_characters#Dende "List of Dragon Ball
characters") heals Videl and discovers that she is pregnant with Gohan's
child. Videl has been hiding the fact to surprise Gohan later and they do not
reveal it to the others yet. When Beerus asks [Mr. Boo](/wiki/Majin_Boo "Majin
Boo") for one or two of the puddings he has, Boo eats all of them, angering
the God of Destruction who decides to destroy the Earth. Boo, [Android
18](/wiki/Android_18 "Android 18"), [Tenshinhan](/wiki/Tenshinhan
"Tenshinhan") and [Piccolo](/wiki/Piccolo_\(Dragon_Ball\) "Piccolo \(Dragon
Ball\)") attempt to fight Beerus, but are easily defeated. Gohan powers up and
attacks Beerus only to be taken down by a heavy kick. Vegeta tries his hand at
defeating Beerus, but he is also taken down.
[Goten](/wiki/List_of_Dragon_Ball_characters#Son_Goten "List of Dragon Ball
characters") and Trunks fuse into Gotenks and attempt to fight Beerus but are
quickly defeated as well.

Bulma becomes annoyed at the fighting ruining her birthday party and yells at
Beerus before slapping him. When Beerus slaps her back, it sends Vegeta into a
fit of rage, becoming even stronger than Goku, however, he is still defeated.
Goku appears, having been watching Vegeta's fight and summons Shenlong to ask
what a Super Saiyan God is. A Super Saiyan God once appeared on planet Vegeta
to stop evil Saiyans, but failed because of the form's time limit. The dragon
also reveals that they need the power of six pure-hearted Saiyans for one of
them to reach the Super Saiyan God form. Goku transforms into a Super Saiyan
God, a form far stronger than even the Super Saiyan 3, thanks to the power of
himself, Vegeta, Gohan, Trunks, Goten, and
[Pan](/wiki/List_of_Dragon_Ball_characters#Pan "List of Dragon Ball
characters") (from inside her mother Videl), fulfilling the prophecy once
stated by the Oracle Fish. Goku confronts Beerus again and they wage an
intense battle in space, right above planet Earth. The form gives Goku the
power to resist Beerus, but he reverts to his regular Super Saiyan form due to
its time limit. However, he learns the form's godlike feeling, which allows
him to use some amount of Super Saiyan God power against Beerus. The two seem
to be equally strong, but Beerus eventually decides to use his strongest
attack. Goku stops the energy sphere, barely holding it back, but after [Chi-
Chi](/wiki/List_of_Dragon_Ball_characters#Chi-Chi "List of Dragon Ball
characters") and Goku's friends appear in Goku's mind he is able to absorb the
energy sphere and briefly transform into a Super Saiyan God once again.
However, Goku is overwhelmed with exhaustion, and at Beerus' suggestion,
finally admits defeat. Beerus recognizes Goku's effort and reveals that he was
the second strongest person he had ever fought, after Whis, who is also his
martial arts master and is even stronger than he is. Goku also learns from
Beerus and Whis that there are actually other universes with other Gods of
Destruction. Back on Earth, Beerus decides to spare the planet and takes his
leave with Whis after bidding farewell to Goku and his friends, who return to
Bulma's birthday party. It is revealed by Whis that Beerus used only 70% of
his power while fighting Goku.

## Development and
production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dragon_Ball_Z:_Battle_of_Gods&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Development and production")]

Early in July 2012, _[Weekly Shōnen Jump](/wiki/Weekly_Sh%C5%8Dnen_Jump
"Weekly Shōnen Jump")'_s official website had already opened a teaser page
with a countdown to a "surprise" on Saturday, July 14, the release date of its
33rd issue of the year. On July 14, the magazine and website, now changed to
show Shenlong appearing and then disappearing, revealed some minor information
of the upcoming film; including the premiere date, staff information, and
companies involved in the production (Fox International Productions Japan,
[Shueisha](/wiki/Shueisha "Shueisha"), [Fuji TV](/wiki/Fuji_TV "Fuji TV"),
[Toei Animation](/wiki/Toei_Animation "Toei Animation"), [Bandai](/wiki/Bandai
"Bandai"), [Bandai Namco Games](/wiki/Bandai_Namco_Games "Bandai Namco
Games"), and [Bird Studio](/wiki/Bird_Studio "Bird Studio")). The film's
director is Masahiro Hosoda, who directed several _Dragon Ball Z_ episodes
back in 1992, the screenplay was written by Yūsuke Watanabe, who has written
manga adaptations before (namely the _[20th Century
Boys](/wiki/20th_Century_Boys "20th Century Boys")_ and _[Gantz](/wiki/Gantz
"Gantz")_ live-action films), and the lead animation director is Tadayoshi
Yamamuro, who has worked on the series since the _Dragon Ball_ anime.[5]

The magazine and official website also published a comment by [Akira
Toriyama](/wiki/Akira_Toriyama "Akira Toriyama") about the movie. The _Dragon
Ball_ series creator notes that the adaptation will mark the first time he has
been so deeply involved in the production of an anime, in this case as early
as the screenwriting stages. Toriyama also said that the film will retain the
atmosphere of the original while adding small amounts of modern flavor.[5]
[Toei Animation](/wiki/Toei_Animation "Toei Animation") released a press
statement on July 17, 2012, saying it would be set "between the animation
series _Z_ and _GT_ , or in other words from the blank decade between the end
of the battle with Majin Boo in chapter 517 of the manga and chapter 518" and
calling it part of "the official history of _Dragon Ball_."[6]

In September, it was announced that the film was one of four that year, and
the only animated one, to receive money from the Japanese government as part
of the non-profit organization UNIJAPAN's "Co-production Certification
Program".[7][8] Toei received 50 million yen (roughly US$636,000) from the
[Agency for Cultural Affairs](/wiki/Agency_for_Cultural_Affairs "Agency for
Cultural Affairs"), whose aim is to promote Japanese arts and culture, with
the United States named as the film's partner country.[7][8]

> This time in particular, we had a request from sensei to leave in not only
> the action, but also some truly enjoyable... the truly enjoyable aspects of
> Dragon Ball; Dragon Ball's chaotic feeling, and the action of Gohan's
> battles and of the Z Fighters are mixed together very well, so I believe
> that has also helped make it an enjoyable movie.
>
> — Gyarmath Bogdan, _MAG Net_ , NHK, March 1, 2013[_[citation
> needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The December issue of _Ultra Jump_ elaborated on Toriyama's involvement in the
movie, stating he came up with the movie's story and character designs.[9] On
December 2, the official website was updated with the movies' cast and entire
staff.[4] The following day, a brief introduction to the film's story was
leaked from accessing an unlinked section of the website.[4]

In January 2013, it was announced that [Olympic](/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic
Games") gold medalist in [judo](/wiki/Judo "Judo") [Kaori
Matsumoto](/wiki/Kaori_Matsumoto "Kaori Matsumoto") and
singer/[tarento](/wiki/Tarento "Tarento") [Shoko
Nakagawa](/wiki/Shoko_Nakagawa "Shoko Nakagawa") will have roles in the
film.[10] Nakagawa is a well-known [otaku](/wiki/Otaku "Otaku") and Matsumoto
is a fan of the series as well.[10] Matsumoto voices a policewoman modeled
after herself, while Nakagawa plays the Yogen-gyo (予言魚) who first leads Beerus
to Goku.[10] The [Fuji TV](/wiki/Fuji_TV "Fuji TV") announcer [Shin-ichi
Karube](/wiki/Mezamashi_TV#Karube_Shinichi "Mezamashi TV") also has a small
part in the movie.

The April issue of _V Jump_ teased about a new Super Saiyan transformation
being in the film, titled "Super Saiyan God" (超サイヤ人ゴッド, _Sūpā Saiya-jin
Goddo_), saying: 39 years ago, the Oracle Fish told Beerus that the Super
Saiyan God would appear before him. And that this is the beginning of the
movie's story.[11] In _Weekly Shōnen Jump_ issue #14 of 2013, Toriyama said
that the plot for _Battle of Gods_ began two years ago with ideas for the God
of Destruction and Super Saiyan God, and that he got deeply involved in the
story in order to keep it in-line with the series' original tone so kids could
enjoy it.[12] In the following week's issue, he revealed that Beerus' design
is based on a cat and his clothes based on Egyptian garments.[13]

A live greeting by cast members and Toriyama, followed by a preview screening
of the film took place across Japan on Tuesday, March 12, 2013, with a limited
number of attendees determined from a _Jump_ lottery. The lottery tickets were
included in 22 different Shueisha magazines (including _Weekly Shōnen Jump_ ,
_V Jump_ , _[Jump SQ](/wiki/Jump_Square "Jump Square")_ , and _[Ultra
Jump](/wiki/Ultra_Jump "Ultra Jump")_) and 884 pairs (1768 people) were
invited. There were five screenings, all the same day and at 6:30 p.m:
Shinjuku Wald 9 cinema in Tokyo (428 people), Umeda Burg 7 theater in Osaka
(440 people), 109 Cinemas in Nagoya (256 people), T-Joy Hakata in Fukuoka (322
people), and Sapporo Cinema Frontier in Sapporo (322 people).[14] The special
cast greeting at the Tokyo venue was beamed live to the other locations before
the screening.[15] A second preview screening with an on-stage greeting and a
special guest took place at [Differ Ariake Arena](/wiki/Differ_Ariake_Arena
"Differ Ariake Arena") on March 16, 2013, with 250 pairs (500 people) invited
(determined with lottery tickets included in _V Jump_ , _Weekly Shōnen Jump_ ,
and _Saikyō Jump_).[15]

###
Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dragon_Ball_Z:_Battle_of_Gods&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Music")]

The music in _Battle of Gods_ was composed by Norihito Sumitomo. Its theme
song is a cover of [Hironobu Kageyama](/wiki/Hironobu_Kageyama "Hironobu
Kageyama")'s "[Cha-La Head-Cha-La](/wiki/Cha-La_Head-Cha-La "Cha-La Head-Cha-
La")", the original opening theme of _Dragon Ball Z_ , by the rock band
[Flow](/wiki/Flow_\(band\) "Flow \(band\)").[16] The band members commented
that they were excited about the opportunity as they have been fans of the
series since they were in elementary school.[16] The cover and the film's
insert song, "[Hero ~Song of Hope~](/wiki/Hero_\(Kib%C5%8D_no_Uta\)_/_Cha-
La_Head-Cha-La "Hero \(Kibō no Uta\) / Cha-La Head-Cha-La")" (HERO~希望の歌~,
_Hīro ~Kibō no Uta~_), were released as a double A-side single on March 20,
2013.[17] It reached number 24 on the [Oricon](/wiki/Oricon "Oricon") Weekly
Singles Chart.[18] The film's original soundtrack, containing 43 tracks, was
released on March 27, 2013.[19] Due to licensing agreements, the international
editions of the film use English-language versions of Flow's "Cha-La Head-Cha-
La" and "Hero ~Song of Hope~".

The music to the trailers in Japan was composed by [Immediate
Music](/wiki/Immediate_Music "Immediate Music") whom specialize in providing
[trailer music](/wiki/Trailer_music "Trailer music") for films, such as
_[Avatar](/wiki/Avatar_\(2009_film\) "Avatar \(2009 film\)")_ , the [_Matrix_
films](/wiki/The_Matrix_\(franchise\) "The Matrix \(franchise\)") and the
[_Harry Potter_ films](/wiki/Harry_Potter_\(film_series\) "Harry Potter \(film
series\)").[20] The trailers use the pieces "Prologue to Conquest"
(Trailerhead: NU EPIQ) and "Emergence of Empires" (Trailerhead: Saga), both
composed by [Yoav Goren](/wiki/Yoav_Goren "Yoav Goren") with the latter based
on "Conquest of Kingdoms" from Epic Choral Action #1 and "Rising Empires" from
_Themes for Orchestra & Choir 2: Abbey Road_ respectively. [Pfeifer Broz.
Music](/wiki/Pfeifer_Broz._Music "Pfeifer Broz. Music") supplied "Evil Island"
for Funimation's promotions and trailers in North America.

##
Marketing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dragon_Ball_Z:_Battle_of_Gods&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Marketing")]

###
Promotions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dragon_Ball_Z:_Battle_of_Gods&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Promotions")]

The July 14, 2012 issue of _Weekly Shōnen Jump_ published the first
promotional images for the film; featuring Goku, Gohan, Piccolo, Kuririn,
Goten, Trunks, Vegeta, and Shenlong, with the tagline "The mightiest make
their move" (最強、始動, _Saikyō, Shidō_), followed by "All humanity has been
waiting. For excitement like none before..." (全人類待望。かつてない興奮へー, _Zen jinrui
taibō. Katsute nai kōfun e_).[5][21] On July 21, 2012, a short teaser trailer
announcing the film was shown at the _Saikyō[V Jump](/wiki/V_Jump "V Jump")_
Festa, and later that

month shown on television.[22] The teaser trailer was added to the movie's
official website in August 2012. In less than a week the video was viewed over
3.5 million times.[23]

With the movie title revealed in November 2012, a special pre-sale
collaboration ticket with the _[One Piece Film: Z](/wiki/One_Piece_Film:_Z
"One Piece Film: Z")_ movie was made to commemorate the release of the two
films. The dual-ticket good for both films has a special new illustration by
both [Eiichirō Oda](/wiki/Eiichir%C5%8D_Oda "Eiichirō Oda") (author of _[One
Piece](/wiki/One_Piece "One Piece")_) and Akira Toriyama.[24] Limited to 8,989
across Japan, the tickets went on sale on November 23, 2012, for ¥2,600
(US$31.51) apiece.[24] The film's poster and two new characters' names and
voice actors were officially revealed in December 2012 in _Weekly Shōnen Jump
'_s first issue of 2013; Beerus, the God of Destruction voiced by [Kōichi
Yamadera](/wiki/K%C5%8Dichi_Yamadera "Kōichi Yamadera") and the mysterious
Whis voiced by [Masakazu Morita](/wiki/Masakazu_Morita "Masakazu Morita").[25]
The film poster displays Super Saiyan Goku combating the God of Destruction
Beerus, with Whis floating showered in light in the background.[25] Various
other characters from the series are also featured on the poster ([Mr.
Satan](/wiki/List_of_Dragon_Ball_characters#Mr._Satan "List of Dragon Ball
characters"), Mr. Boo, Videl, the shrunken Pilaf gang, Super Saiyan Goten,
Super Saiyan Gohan, Super Saiyan Vegeta, Super Saiyan Trunks, Bulma, Piccolo,
Tenshinhan, Kuririn, [Yamcha](/wiki/List_of_Dragon_Ball_characters#Yamcha
"List of Dragon Ball characters") and
[Puar](/wiki/List_of_Dragon_Ball_characters#Pu.27ar "List of Dragon Ball
characters")).[25]

The first full trailer for the film was aired on Fuji TV on December 7, 2012,
during the morning show _Mezamashi TV_.[26] A 30-minute _Battle of Gods_
discussion panel was held at Jump Festa 2013; on the Jump Super Stage, on
December 22, 2012. Along with the voice actors [Masako
Nozawa](/wiki/Masako_Nozawa "Masako Nozawa"), [Mayumi
Tanaka](/wiki/Mayumi_Tanaka "Mayumi Tanaka"), [Toshio
Furukawa](/wiki/Toshio_Furukawa "Toshio Furukawa"), the film director Masahiro
Hosoda, _V Jump_ editor-in-chief Akio Iyoku, and Toei Animation producer
Gyarmath Bogdan took part at the discussion which was overseen by former YBS
TV announcer Mariko Nakagomi. The second full trailer for the film began being
streamed on Cinema Today's website on February 27, 2013.[27] In late March
2013, Cinema Today's website began streaming a TV ad for the movie that
features Frieza ([Ryūsei Nakao](/wiki/Ry%C5%ABsei_Nakao "Ryūsei Nakao")) and
[Cell](/wiki/Cell_\(Dragon_Ball\) "Cell \(Dragon Ball\)") ([Norio
Wakamoto](/wiki/Norio_Wakamoto "Norio Wakamoto")); Cell questions why he isn't
in the film and Frieza brags that he is, Cell then remarks that Frieza only
has a non-speaking appearance.[28]

###
Collaborations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dragon_Ball_Z:_Battle_of_Gods&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Collaborations")]

During the 30th Prize Fair, which took place in Tokyo on November 7, 2012,
Bandai showcased some of their new _Dragon Ball_ figures for winter 2012, as
well their World Collectable Figure line produced in conjunction with the 2013
movie. The latter is a set of eight figures around 7 cm tall that covers
characters that appear in the movie; along with Vegeta and Super Saiyan 3
Goku, the three members of the Pilaf gang were among the figures revealed.

In February 2013, several collaborative projects between _Dragon Ball Z:
Battle of Gods_ and [KFC](/wiki/KFC "KFC") in Japan began. On the seventh, the
restaurants began selling "Smile Sets with Strongest Battle Goods — Parents
and Kids Play Together!", which came with _Dragon Ball Z_ games such as
reversi and playing cards.[29] On the fifteenth, the KFC restaurants in
Sapporo, Sendai, Ebisu, Sakae, Osaka, Hakata and Okinawa dressed their
[Colonel Sanders](/wiki/Colonel_Sanders "Colonel Sanders") statues as Goku,
with each one holding a different starred Dragon Ball.[30] They began selling
"Strongest Sets" that come with "Light Up! Dragon Bottles" or "Dream Dragon
Radar detectors" on February 28, and a TV ad featuring Goku began
airing.[30][31]

As part of a collaboration with the Japanese [J. League Division
1](/wiki/J._League_Division_1 "J. League Division 1") football team [Albirex
Niigata](/wiki/Albirex_Niigata "Albirex Niigata"), a special poster unveiled
on the official _Battle of Gods_ website on February 20, 2013, was displayed
across Niigata Prefecture in promotion of their match with the defending
league Division 1 champions [Sanfrecce Hiroshima](/wiki/Sanfrecce_Hiroshima
"Sanfrecce Hiroshima") on March 3, 2013.[32] The poster is based on the
_Battle of Gods_ poster, with the movie characters replaced by the football
team's players: the figure in the background replacing Whis is the team's
manager Masaaki Yanagishita, Beerus has been replaced by the Sanfrecce
Hiroshima goalkeeper Shūsaku Nishikawa, and Goku is replaced by the team's
forward Bruno Lopes. All supporters at the match wore orange, Goku made an
"appearance" at the stadium, and the _Dragon Ball Z_ theme song was used.

From March 5 to April 8 the [Lawson](/wiki/Lawson_\(store\) "Lawson
\(store\)") convenience stores sold special _Battle of Gods_ inspired food
items, such as Dragon Ball pizza balls, Super Saiyan fries, Demon King
Piccolo's Green Tea Cream Puffs, Majin Boo Milk Pudding and Vegeta's Green
Salad.[33]

### Tie-ins with other
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dragon_Ball_Z:_Battle_of_Gods&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Tie-ins with other media")]

The March 2013 issue of _V Jump_ revealed that Beerus would appear in the
_Dragon Ball Heroes_ arcade game as a boss battle,[15] and subsequently in its
Nintendo 3DS version titled _Dragon Ball Heroes: Ultimate Mission_. It also
announced the _Dragon Ball Z_ Festival at [Toei Kyoto Studio
Park](/wiki/Toei_Kyoto_Studio_Park "Toei Kyoto Studio Park") from March 16 to
September 8 in celebration of _Battle of the Gods_.[15] Starting on March 30,
Beerus appeared in the _Dragon Ball_ arcade game _Zenkai Battle Royale_.
Beerus, Whis, and Goku's Super Saiyan God form are all playable characters in
the video game _[Battle of Z](/wiki/Dragon_Ball_Z:_Battle_of_Z "Dragon Ball Z:
Battle of Z")_.[34]

A manga adaptation of _Battle of Gods_ ran in the April 2013 issue of _[Saikyō
Jump](/wiki/Saiky%C5%8D_Jump "Saikyō Jump")_ , which went on sale on March 4,
2013.[35] Drawn by Naho Ōishi, who currently draws the _Dragon Ball SD_ series
in the magazine and previously _[Dragon Ball: Episode of
Bardock](/wiki/Dragon_Ball:_Episode_of_Bardock "Dragon Ball: Episode of
Bardock")_ in _V Jump_ , it depicts the beginning of the film. An [anime
comic](/wiki/Film_comic "Film comic") version, more commonly known as "ani-
manga" in the west, of _Battle of Gods_ was released on October 4, 2013.[36]

_Battle of Gods_ received its television debut on Fuji TV on March 22, 2014 at
9:00pm.[37] Toei Animation producer Gyarmath Bogdan confirmed through
[Twitter](/wiki/Twitter "Twitter") that the broadcast included up to twenty
minutes of extra scenes and additional footage.[1] The broadcast earned an
average household rating of 13.1%.[38]

The 2015 _[Dragon Ball Z:
Resurrection'F'](/wiki/Dragon_Ball_Z:_Resurrection_%27F%27 "Dragon Ball Z:
Resurrection 'F'")_ film is a sequel to _Battle of Gods_ and features Beerus
and Whis.[39]

The first story arc of _[Dragon Ball Super](/wiki/Dragon_Ball_Super "Dragon
Ball Super")_ is a retelling of sorts of _Battle of Gods_ , though some events
are altered or expanded in the series' version of events. The "Battle of Gods"
arc covers [episodes
1-14](/wiki/List_of_Dragon_Ball_Super_episodes#Battle_of_Gods_Saga "List of
Dragon Ball Super episodes").

## Release and
reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dragon_Ball_Z:_Battle_of_Gods&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Release and reception")]

_Battle of Gods_ is the first-ever Japanese film to be screened at
[IMAX](/wiki/IMAX "IMAX") Digital Theaters, screening at all 16 [IMAX Digital
Theater](/wiki/List_of_IMAX_venues#J "List of IMAX venues") locations across
Japan.[40][41] However, it was not shown in 3D.[42]

[Madman Entertainment](/wiki/Madman_Entertainment "Madman Entertainment")
announced they had acquired the [Australasian](/wiki/Australasia
"Australasia") rights to the film and screened the movie at the 2013 Japanese
Film Festival in Australia from October to December.[43] On May 30, 2014,
Funimation announced that they had acquired the North American rights to the
movie and gave the film a limited theatrical run in North America from August
5–7 and 9, 2014.[44] Funimation held a red carpet premiere for _Dragon Ball Z:
Battle of Gods_ in Los Angeles on July 3. The 8:00 p.m. red carpet and 9:00
p.m. screening was at the Regal LA Live Stadium 14 Theaters.[45] Madman
screened Funimation's dub at a handful of Australasian theaters on August 30,
2014.[46] [Manga Entertainment](/wiki/Manga_Entertainment "Manga
Entertainment"), the United Kingdom's distributor of the series, announced at
the MCM Manchester Comic Con that they licensed the film and would give it a
limited theatrical release, including an appearance at the 2014 [Scotland
Loves Anime](/wiki/Scotland_Loves_Animation "Scotland Loves Animation")
convention.[47]

In [Latin America](/wiki/Latin_America "Latin America"), the movie was
released by Diamond Films during the last days of September and first days of
October 2013 (depending on the country) with almost every member of the
original cast from the Mexican Spanish dub of the series. In Brazil, _Battle
of Gods_ was released by Diamond Filmes on October 11, 2013, with the original
cast from the Brazilian Portuguese _Dragon Ball Z_ dub.[48] In Italy the movie
entered theaters on February 1, 2014.

In Spain, the movie was released in theaters on May 30, 2014 in Castilian
Spanish, Catalan and Basque languages, with the former bringing back almost
every member of the original cast from the Castilian Spanish _Dragon Ball Z_
dub while the latter two feature the respective Catalan and Basque voice casts
from _Dragon Ball Kai_ (the Catalan voice cast also being essentially the same
one from _Dragon Ball Z_). The extended version home release also featured a
Valencian dub with almost every member of the original cast from the Valencian
_Dragon Ball Z_ dub.

In [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines"), the movie was released
subtitled in English by Pioneer Films during the month of April 2013, making
it the second _Dragon Ball_ film to be shown in the country. The
[Filipino](/wiki/Filipino_language "Filipino language") dub of the movie will
be released on January 4, 2015 by [ABS-CBN](/wiki/ABS-CBN "ABS-CBN") TV
Network.

### Box
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dragon_Ball_Z:_Battle_of_Gods&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Box office")]

_Dragon Ball Z: Battle of Gods_ opened at number one in the Japanese box
office, earning US$7,307,760 with 561,098 tickets sold in its first two
days.[49][50] The movie's showings at all 16 of the IMAX Digital theaters in
Japan that weekend earned US$450,000, with an average of US$28,000 per
screen.[51] It was ranked number five in the overseas box office chart by
_[Variety](/wiki/Variety_\(magazine\) "Variety \(magazine\)")_ , making it the
top-grossing non-American film on the chart.[51][52] While the top four films
are playing in over 50 territories each, _Battle of Gods_ ' performance is
based only on 328 screens in Japan.[52] By its fifth day, the film had made
over US$12,000,000 with 988,790 tickets sold.[53] As a result, the film was
projected to sell more than 1 million tickets by its sixth day, making it the
fastest film to reach that milestone so far that year in Japan.[53] It was
number one in its second week as well, with a total of 1,488,518 tickets sold
and an estimated US$19,017,008 total earnings.[54][55] The film was number one
for a third week, raising its total to US$23,618,327 with 1,823,141 tickets
sold, making it the fastest-grossing film of 2013 in Japan.[56][57] It dropped
to fourth place the subsequent weekend of April 20–21, but total tickets sold
passed the two million mark and its total revenue climbed to
US$26,419,641.[58][59] The film dropped to eighth during [Golden
Week](/wiki/Golden_Week_\(Japan\) "Golden Week \(Japan\)"), which is when many
new movies open in theaters and is the film industry's best week in Japan,
while the box office gross grew to US$28,162,444 and tickets reached
2,181,328.[60][61] The following week it held on to the eighth place, with
tickets sold increasing to 2,346,726 and its gross to US$29,172,291.[62][63]

Toei aimed for _Battle of Gods_ to earn a domestic Japanese box office take of
¥3 billion (about US$30 million).[64] In December 2013, Oricon listed _Battle
of Gods_ as the Japanese box office's eleventh highest-grossing film of the
year earning a box office take of ¥3 billion.[65] The film earned US$2.8
million in North American theaters in 8 days,[66] placing it eleventh on a
list of the highest-grossing theatrically released anime in North America of
all time according to [Box Office Mojo](/wiki/Box_Office_Mojo "Box Office
Mojo").

### Critical
reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dragon_Ball_Z:_Battle_of_Gods&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Critical reception")]

Richard Eisenbeis writing for [Kotaku](/wiki/Kotaku "Kotaku") called the film
"a great nostalgic trip from beginning to end."[67] He noted that it was
focused on lighthearted moments, but that the "comedic moments were not only
funny but also true to the series, and the fight scenes were excellent one and
all."[67] He particularly praised the animation as the best of the series, due
to technological advancements since the early 1990s, and declared that the
highlight of the movie was how in the end the villain was undoubtedly the
winner over Goku in a "complete reversal of the standard DBZ formula".[67]
_[Otaku USA](/wiki/Otaku_USA "Otaku USA")'_s Matt Schley agreed that it is a
comedy heavy film "more reminiscent of the original _Dragon Ball_ than Z".[68]
He speculates that the viewer's enjoyment of the movie depends on what they
expect; "If you want epic _Dragon Ball Z_ story worthy of the title _Battle of
Gods_ , this film may disappoint. But if you’re just happy to see your
favorite characters performing a few animated hijinx again after all these
years, this film certainly delivers."[68]

Leah B. Jackson of [IGN](/wiki/IGN "IGN") gave the English dub of the movie a
7.5 out of 10, praising the animation and fight scenes, particularly the final
battle. She was pleased to see Funimation's voice actors return, but
criticized the movie for the lack of iconic techniques and having too much
"filler".[69] Theron Martin of _[Anime News Network](/wiki/Anime_News_Network
"Anime News Network")_ (ANN) praised the movie for its humor, use of main and
supporting cast, the introduction of Beerus and Whis and the overall light-
hearted nature and plot. But also criticized the movie for its inconsistent
animation, uninspiring fight scenes and use of CGI, stating, "Ultimately
Battle of Gods is entirely a movie for long-established fans, as it has too
many in-jokes that those not familiar with wide swaths of the franchise would
get. It is not a stellar addition to the franchise but is a worthwhile and at
least moderately entertaining one, provided that one does not go into it
expecting an action magnum opus."[70] Kyle Mills Of [DVD Talk](/wiki/DVD_Talk
"DVD Talk") highly recommended the movie, praising the dub and the perfect
balancing of the humor elements from the first _Dragon Ball_ anime with the
action elements of _Dragon Ball Z_. He finished with, "Dragon Ball Z: Battle
of Gods is one hell of a fun flick. For any fan of the Dragon Ball franchise,
you need to check it out.[...] [It is] a film full of nostalgia, fun
characters, legitimate laugh out loud moments, and slick action sequences.
It's a film that showcases perfectly why the Dragon Ball franchise has such
long lasting popularity."[71]

### Home
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Dragon_Ball_Z:_Battle_of_Gods&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Home media")]

The film was released in Japan in standard and limited edition [DVD](/wiki/DVD
"DVD") and [Blu-ray](/wiki/Blu-ray "Blu-ray") formats on September 13,
2013.[72] In addition to the design material and trailer collections included
in the regular edition, the limited edition includes behind the scenes
footage, interviews, and the 2008 short film _[Dragon Ball: Yo! Son Goku and
His Friends Return!!](/wiki/Dragon_Ball:_Yo!_Son_Goku_and_His_Friends_Return!!
"Dragon Ball: Yo! Son Goku and His Friends Return!!")_ , as well as a figure,
booklet, and special postcards. The home video release of _Battle of Gods_
sold approximately 50,381 copies in its first week.[73][74] By the end of the
year, it had sold 46,761 DVDs and 33,737 Blu-rays.[75][76] The extended TV
version of the film was released on DVD and Blu-ray on March 13, 2015,[77]
selling approximately 1,666 copies in its first week.[78][79]

Funimation released the theatrical and extended TV versions in North America
on DVD and Blu-ray on October 7, 2014.[80] A similar set was released in the
United Kingdom by Manga Entertainment on November 10, 2014.[81] Madman
Entertainment released the film in Australia and New Zealand on DVD and Blu-
ray on November 26, 2014.
